parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>RV</title><part><name>type</name>=<value>command

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> arma1

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Program Flow

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.00

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> Breaks the code execution out of scope {} named ''name''. [[nil]] is returned. Scope name can be assigned using [[scopeName]] command.
<template lineStart="1"><title>Feature</title><part><name index="1"/><value>important</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>An unknown [[scopeName]] name will cause the script error <template><title>ic</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Generic error in expression</value></part></template></value></part></template>
<template lineStart="1"><title>Feature</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Informative</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>An empty [[scopeName]] name will immediately leave the current scope</value></part></template>
<br><br>
Since Arma 3 v1.47, [[breakOut]] can be used to return a ''value''. It is the closest SQF comes to having "return"-like operation.

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> '''breakOut''' name

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> name: [[String]] - name of the scope (previously set with [[scopeName]])

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Nothing]]

</value></part><part><name>s2</name>=<value> value '''breakOut''' name <template><title>Since</title><part><name index="1"/><value>arma3</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.47</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value>y</value></part></template>

</value></part><part><name>p21</name>=<value> value: [[Anything]] - a value to return

</value></part><part><name>p22</name>=<value> name: [[String]] - name of the scope (previously set with [[scopeName]])

</value></part><part><name>r2</name>=<value> [[Anything]]

</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>[[scopeName]] "main";
[[while]] {[[true]]} [[do]] {
	[[scopeName]] "loop1";
	[[while]] {[[true]]} [[do]] {
		[[scopeName]] "loop2";
		[[if]] (condition1) [[then]] {[[breakTo]] "main"}; <template><title>cc</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Breaks all scopes and return to "main"</value></part></template>
		[[if]] (condition2) [[then]] {[[breakOut]] "loop2"}; <template><title>cc</title><part><name index="1"/><value>Breaks scope named "loop2"</value></part></template>
		[[sleep]] 1;
	};
	[[sleep]] 1;
};
</code>

</value></part><part><name>x2</name>=<value> <code>[[call]] {
	[[scopeName]] "main"; 
	[[call]] {
		123 [[breakOut]] "main"
	};
	345
}; <template><title>cc</title><part><name index="1"/><value>call returns 123</value></part></template></code>

</value></part><part><name>seealso</name>=<value> [[scopeName]], [[breakTo]], [[exitWith]]
</value></part></template>


<comment><!-- CONTINUE Notes -->
</comment><dl class="command_description">
<dd class="notedate">Posted on August 27, 2015 - 16:09 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Polaris|Polaris]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
breakOut can still be used if multiple scopes share identical names. It will simply break out of the nearest scope that matches the name parameter you've used. For example:
<code>[[call]] {
	[[scopeName]] "Main"; [[a / b|/]]/Parent Ma[[in]]
	[[call]] {
		[[scopeName]] "Main"; [[a / b|/]]/Child Ma[[in]]
		"String" [[breakOut]] "Main"; [[a / b|/]]/Will break out of child ma[[in]] [[and]] return "String" [[to]] parent ma[[in]]
	};
};
</code>
Therefore you are able to consistently reuse scope names such as "Main", "Child", "Primary", "Secondary", etc throughout functions without worrying about having to ensure you create unique names for each scope.
</dd>
</dl>
<comment><!-- DISCONTINUE Notes -->
</comment>

<template lineStart="1"><title>GameCategory</title><part><name index="1"/><value>tkoh</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>Scripting Commands</value></part></template></root>
